class_notes:
(Same as LING 385W 1)
During the late Middle Ages (1100 to 1500) what the Angles and Saxons called "Englisc" became the language we speak today.  This "middle" period bridged biblical, classical, Germanic and Celtic traditions to our modern ideas of what the English language is and who the English people are, both in space and time.  English speakers come in many varieties, linguistically and ethnically.  We will read a selection of Middle English lyrics, drama, narrative poetry, and prose, including the following sub-genres: alliterative long line (Brut); dream vision (Pearl and Piers Plowman); Romance (Sir Orfeo); fabliau (Dame Sirith); Arthurian history (Malory's Morte Darthur).
course_description: Representative works of Middle English literature from 1100 to 1500, exclusive of Chaucer.
schedule_location: MW 8:30am-9:45am in Math & Science Center - N304
